key_points: US-led coalition bombs Taliban and al-Qaeda facilities in Afghanistan, targeting Kabul, Kandahar, and Jalalabad.
The Taliban, in control after Soviet occupation and civil war, do not surrender Bin Laden. Their defense capabilities are destroyed.
A new Afghan constitution is established after negotiations, leading to presidential elections in October 2004.
NATO ends its combat operations in Afghanistan, transitioning the US focus to training and supporting Afghan security forces.
Afghan President Ashraf Ghani reports over 45,000 members of the country's security forces have died since 2014, a higher figure than previously known.
US President Joe Biden announces a final withdrawal date of 11 September 2021 for all US troops from Afghanistan.
The timeline captures key moments from the initial airstrikes against Taliban and al-Qaeda to the planned full withdrawal of US forces.
This overview highlights the long-term involvement and impact of foreign military presence in Afghanistan.
It outlines significant political and military transitions in Afghanistan over nearly two decades.
The announcement of troop withdrawal marks a significant shift towards ending America's longest war.
